trans-unit.source: Acute gastritis, with haemorrhage
ICF Version 2.0
<cf w:eastAsia="Calibri" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">IRB APPROVED</cf>
<cf w:eastAsia="Calibri" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">AS MODIFIED</cf>
<cf w:eastAsia="Calibri" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">Aug 11, 2023</cf>
<cf bold="on" size="12">TITLE:
</cf><cf size="12">Flow Regulation by Opening the SepTum in Patients with Heart Failure; a prospective, randomized, sham-controlled, double blind, global multicenter study.</cf>
trans-unit.note: Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Blind = Blind
Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Blind = Blind

trans-unit.source: <cf bold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">PROTOCOL NO.:</cf><cf size="12" complexscriptssize="12">
WCG IRB Protocol #20216194</cf>
<cf bold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">SPONSOR:</cf><cf size="12" complexscriptssize="12">
Occlutech US LLC</cf>
<cf bold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">INVESTIGATOR:
<cf bold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">STUDY-RELATED</cf>
<cf bold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">PHONE NUMBER(S):</cf><cf size="12" complexscriptssize="12">
INTRODUCTION
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Why am I being asked to provide my consent? </cf>
This is a research study, which is different than personal medical care. Scientists do research to answer important questions which might help change or improve the way we do things in the future.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Do I have to join this research study? </cf>
No. Taking part in this research study is voluntary.
You may choose not to take part in the study or may choose to leave the study at any time.
Deciding not to participate, or deciding to leave the study later, will not result in any penalty or loss of benefits to which you are entitled.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Why is this research study being done?</cf>

The purpose of this clinical study is to assess the safety and effectiveness of the Atrial Flow Regulator (also called the study device) in the treatment of subjects, 18 years of age or older, who have symptomatic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) or heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) while on stable guideline directed medical therapy (GDMT) as outlined in the Guidelines for the Management of Heart Failure.
trans-unit.note: Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit erhaltener Auswurffraktion Ejection fraction = Auswurffraktion Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit verringerter Auswurffraktion

Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit erhaltener Auswurffraktion Ejection fraction = Auswurffraktion Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit verringerter Auswurffraktion

trans-unit.source: <cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">What will happen to me during the study? </cf>
If you decide to join this research study (and are not a “roll-in” subject), you will be randomly assigned to one of three groups:
the investigational device group with 6 millimeter opening, 2) the investigational device with 8 millimeter opening, or 3) the sham procedure group.
Sham procedures are like the investigational device group but the device will not actually be implanted.
Being randomly assigned happens by chance, much like the result of flipping a coin.
You have a one in three chance of being assigned to each group (device 6 vs. device 8 vs. sham).
This is blinded study, meaning that the assigned treatment group is hidden from study participants and site study staff.
You will not know whether you were assigned to the investigational device or the sham procedure group until after you complete your 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit.
The doctor and staff you see for follow-up visits will also be blinded to your treatment group until after your 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">How long will I participate? </cf>
The total study duration is expected to be about 7 years with your study participation expected to be 5 years.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Will taking part expose me to risks? </cf>
While physicians and hospital staff will take all precautions necessary to ensure your safety and well-being, it is impossible to anticipate all potential risks/side effects.
You will be informed about the risks related to the procedure, implantation, and examination methods by your study doctor.
Our experience with the Atrial Flow Regulator is still limited, therefore not all risk factors are known yet.
Reasonably foreseeable risks include excess fluid in the lungs, infections, and irregular heart rhythm.
A more comprehensive list is included later in this form.
You will be carefully monitored throughout the study to identify any risks and/or side effects.
Please inform the study doctor immediately if you notice changes in your health condition.
You will be notified if previously unknown risk factors become known during the duration of the study.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Are there any benefits to participation? </cf>
Having the Atrial Flow Regulator implanted may relieve some of your heart failure symptoms without open-heart surgery and you may be able to stop some medications.
trans-unit.note: Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Surgery = Operativer Eingriff
Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Surgery = Operativer Eingriff

trans-unit.source: Usually, the pain after the implant procedure is much less than open- heart surgery and your stay in the hospital is usually much shorter.
The recovery time can be faster and there is little scarring.
There is no guarantee that you will personally benefit from participation in this study.
However, it is possible that the experience gained from the study can help future patients.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">What are my alternatives to participation?
If you choose not to participate in this study at this time, your doctor will discuss alternative treatments with you.
Treatment options may include additional medication, implantation of FDA approved devices, the use of drugs to prevent the occurrence of symptoms, or not having any treatment at all.
Your doctor will explain the benefits and risks associated with the implantation of the Atrial Flow Regulator and the sham procedure, as well as the alternative treatments to you.
Please ask your doctor if you have any questions.
If you do not wish to take part in the study, you will receive the established treatment/ one of the alternative treatments mentioned above.
No disadvantage of any kind shall arise for you.
Your doctor has told you that you have Heart Failure and that your symptoms continue despite standard of care treatment.
Your doctor may have performed tests to confirm your diagnosis.
Due to your history of heart failure and current symptoms, your doctor has invited you to participate in this research study.
This study compares the use of a new investigational product, the Atrial Flow Regulator (AFR) device and its delivery system, to a sham procedure.
A sham procedure is an inactive treatment or procedure that is intended to mimic as closely as possible the interventional procedure, but will not implant a device.
Your doctor has given you this form to tell you about this research study and to ask for your consent to join this research study.
Your consent to join the study, if given, will be documented by your signature on the last page of this form, only after you fully understand the study.

The purpose of this clinical study is to assess the safety and effectiveness of the Atrial Flow Regulator (also called the study device) in the treatment of subjects, 18 years of age or older, who have symptomatic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) or heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) while on stable guideline directed medical therapy (GDMT) as outlined in the Guidelines for the Management of Heart Failure.
trans-unit.note: Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit erhaltener Auswurffraktion Ejection fraction = Auswurffraktion Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit verringerter Auswurffraktion

Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit erhaltener Auswurffraktion Ejection fraction = Auswurffraktion Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction = Herzinsuffizienz mit verringerter Auswurffraktion

trans-unit.source: This study will be conducted at up to 150 centers in the U.S., Canada, Europe and Asia Pacific may participate in this study.
Approximately 588 subjects and <bookmarkStart number="0" w:name="_Hlk112412543"/>approximately<bookmarkEnd number="0"/> 110 roll-in subjects will be participating in this study.
<bookmarkStart number="1" w:name="_Hlk112412648"/>If you are part of the “roll-in” group, you<bookmarkEnd number="1"/> will receive the AFR device (and will not be randomized to device/sham).
The total study duration is expected to be about 7 years with your study participation expected to be 5 years.
<br w:type="page"/>STUDY PROCEDURE
If you decide to join this research study (and are not a “roll-in” subject), you will be randomly assigned to one of three groups:
<cf size="12">the investigational device group with 6 millimeter opening, 2) the investigational device with 8 millimeter opening, or 3) the sham procedure group.
Sham procedures are like the investigational device group but the device will not actually be implanted.
Being randomly assigned happens by chance, much like </cf><bookmarkStart number="2" w:name="_Hlk112412714"/><cf size="12">the result of flipping a coin</cf><bookmarkEnd number="2"/><cf size="12">.
You have a one in three chance of being assigned to each group (device 6 vs. device 8 vs. sham).</cf>
<cf size="12">This is blinded study, meaning that the assigned treatment group is hidden from study participants and site study staff.
You will not know whether you were assigned to the investigational device or the sham procedure group until after you complete your 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit.
The doctor and staff you see for follow-up visits will also be blinded to your treatment group until after your 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit.
<cf bold="on">Baseline Evaluation</cf>
You will have the following tests done prior to joining in the study.
These tests are considered standard of care and would be performed even if you did not join the study.
<cf size="12">Medical history and risk factors</cf>
<cf size="12">ECG</cf>
<cf size="12">Blood tests</cf>
<bookmarkStart number="3" w:name="_Hlk112412766"/><cf size="12">Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)</cf>
trans-unit.note: Transesophageal echocardiography = Transoesophageale Echokardiographie Echocardiography = Echokardiographie
Transesophageal echocardiography = Transoesophageale Echokardiographie Echocardiography = Echokardiographie

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Six-minute walking test</cf><bookmarkEnd number="3"/>
<cf size="12">If you decide to participate in the study and sign this consent form, you will have some additional testing to make sure you are eligible for the study:
<cf size="12">Questionnaires about your quality of life</cf>
<cf bold="on">Device Implantation or Sham Procedure</cf>
You will be randomly assigned to either having the Atrial Flow Regulator implanted, or having a sham procedure without having a device implanted.
You will be required to take an anti-platelet, such as clopidogrel every day for three- months and aspirin every day for six months after the procedure.
If you assigned to the sham procedure group, you will be given placebo (inactive) pills instead of clopidogrel and aspirin.
The Atrial Flow Regulator is a self-expandable, double disc device made from a wire mesh.
The two discs are linked together by a short connecting waist.
Each device has a hole (shunt) of either 6 millimeters or 8 millimeters diameter (width).
The materials used in the in the device are the same as that used by surgeons for other cardiac treatments.
The Atrial Flow Regulator will remain implanted in your heart.
The sham procedure will allow the surgeon to take detailed measurements of your heart function, but no devices or therapy will be administered.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on" fontcolor="auto">Figure </cf><field Id="1" text="SEQ"/><cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on" fontcolor="auto">:
Atrial Flow Regulator</cf>
You will have either procedure in the cardiac catheterization laboratory, or “cath lab”, or a procedure room.
Local or general anesthesia will be used and there should not be significant discomfort.
trans-unit.note: General anesthesia = Allgemeine Anaesthesie Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Discomfort = Unbehagen
General anesthesia = Allgemeine Anaesthesie Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Discomfort = Unbehagen

trans-unit.source: This is a non-surgical, minimally invasive procedure done using <bookmarkStart number="4" w:name="_Hlk112412827"/>echocardiography<bookmarkEnd number="4"/> guidance in which a catheter is inserted through a blood vessel in your thigh up into your heart.
trans-unit.note: Invasive procedure = Invasives Verfahren Echocardiography = Echokardiographie
Invasive procedure = Invasives Verfahren Echocardiography = Echokardiographie

trans-unit.source: A catheter is a sterile, flexible, hollow tube that is inserted into a blood vessel to allow for injection or removal of fluids or to pass devices through.
After the procedure, you may experience some discomfort in the area where the catheter was inserted.
To help your doctor evaluate your heart during the procedure, you will have a Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE) or Intracardiac Echocardiography (ICE).
trans-unit.note: Transesophageal echocardiography = Transoesophageale Echokardiographie Echocardiography = Echokardiographie
Transesophageal echocardiography = Transoesophageale Echokardiographie Echocardiography = Echokardiographie

trans-unit.source: The TEE is an ultrasound test to see your heart, where an imaging probe is placed through your mouth and passed into your esophagus.
Some soreness may persist in your throat for about one week.
If your doctor decides to look at your heart using ICE, the doctor will pass an ICE imaging probe through a blood vessel in your thigh up into your heart.
After your doctor has accessed your heart and measured your heart pressures, the doctor will make sure you meet the criteria to be included in the study.
If you meet criteria, you will be randomly assigned to receive the AFR with 6mm hole, AFR with 8mm hole, or sham procedure.
If you do not meet criteria, you will not be included in the study and your doctor will continue to treat you according to standard of care.
If you are randomized to the AFR device with either the 6mm or 8mm hole, the study procedure will be the same.
A standard guidewire will be used to access the right side of your heart through a large vein in your upper leg.
A catheter will be placed over the wire in the same fashion.
Your doctor will then create a hole in the atrial septum, the tissue that separates the left side of the heart from the right side.
Once there is a connection from right to left, the AFR device is passed through the catheter and positioned in the middle of your left atrium.
The left disk is deployed, and then drawn against the atrial septum.
The right disc is then deployed.
After your doctor is satisfied with the position of the device, it is released from the delivery cable using a screw mechanism.
The duration of the procedure will be about 1-2 hours but can vary depending on needs.
There will be a sponsor representative present at cases to support the study doctor during implant.
If you are randomized to the sham procedure, you will have the same wire and catheter access to the right side of your heart.
Heart pressures will be measured, but no hole will be created in the tissue that separates the right and left side of your heart and no device will be implanted.
After recovery from sedation or anesthesia and a few hours of bed rest, you should be able to sit up and walk around.
trans-unit.note: Sedation = Sedierung Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Bed rest = Bettruhe
Sedation = Sedierung Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Bed rest = Bettruhe

trans-unit.source: Before you are discharged from the hospital, an electrocardiogram (ECG) and physical exam will be done to assess if you are well enough to go home.
After you are sent home, you will be required to take clopidogrel every day for three months and aspirin every day for six months after the procedure to make sure no blood clots form on your device.
You may already be taking an anti-platelet such as clopidogrel and aspirin for other reasons.
Your doctor may decide to keep you on clopidogrel and aspirin after the required six months if it is in your best interest.
If you had the sham procedure, your doctor may prescribe placebo (sugar pills) instead of clopidogrel and aspirin.

To prevent against certain bacterial infections, you may need to take some doses of an antibiotic during the first six months following the placement of the device, especially if you are planning to undergo certain procedures such as dental cleanings.

All patients will receive a patient card with information about their procedure <bookmarkStart number="5" w:name="_Hlk112412916"/>regardless if<bookmarkEnd number="5"/> they were randomly selected to receive the implanted device or the sham procedure.
The patient card will also have the contact details to the study hospital.

<bookmarkStart number="6" w:name="_Hlk112412941"/>Since you are in a blinded study, you should show this card to medical staff to inform them to keep you blinded if you have a chest x-ray or other assessment that could possibly unblind you.
trans-unit.note: Chest X-ray = Roentgen Thorax X-ray = Roentgen
Chest X-ray = Roentgen Thorax X-ray = Roentgen

trans-unit.source: Following your discharge there will be several follow up visits.
You will be asked to come for your study visits at 1-, 6-, 12- and 24-months after your procedure.

Some of the assessments at these visits include a clinical assessment and physical exam, a six (6) minute walk test, ECG, laboratory, medication and adverse event assessments and study questionnaires.
trans-unit.note: ECG = EKG Adverse event = Unerwuenschtes Ereignis
ECG = EKG Adverse event = Unerwuenschtes Ereignis

trans-unit.source: After your 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit, you will be told whether you received the AFR device or the sham procedure.
If you had the sham procedure, you will be given the option to “cross-over” and receive the AFR device implant after the 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit.
If you would like to have the AFR device implanted, your study doctor will evaluate your symptoms and make sure you still meet all criteria.
If you meet all criteria, your procedure will be scheduled and will be completed as described above.
Patients that elect to have the AFR device implanted after their 2-year (24-month) follow-up visit will be followed until they have been in the study for a total of 5 years.
These follow-up visits occurring after the cross-over AFR implant include a 6-month, 12-month and annual visit until total study participation has reached 5 years (60-months).
The assessments completed during these visits are similar to the assessments you completed during the first two years of the study.

Once you have completed your follow-up visits as part of the investigational study, you will be given the option to participate in a post-approval study that will collect long term safety and efficacy data.
WHAT WE EXPECT FROM YOU
You are requested to be available for all scheduled appointments at the study site.
Please report all changes in your physical health to the study doctor.
Also, all medication you are taking during the study, both prescription and non-prescription drugs must be disclosed to the study doctor.
Please follow all the instructions of the study doctor and their medical staff carefully.<cf style="normaltextrun">
Tell your study doctor if you become aware of your randomization assignment (device vs sham) during the first two years of your study participation.</cf>
<cf style="normaltextrun">Because you are in this clinical investigation, you may need to visit your doctor more frequently than standard of care, which may be an inconvenience to you.</cf>
FORESEEABLE RISKS AND SIDE EFFECTS
While physicians and hospital staff will take all precautions necessary to ensure your safety and well-being, it is impossible to anticipate all potential risks/side effects.
You will be informed about the risks related to the procedure, implantation, and examination methods by your study doctor.
Our experience with the Atrial Flow Regulator is still limited, therefore not all risk factors are known yet.
You will be carefully monitored throughout the study to identify any risks and/or side effects.
Please inform the study doctor immediately if you notice changes in your health condition.
You will be notified if previously unknown risk factors become known during the duration of the study.
The implantation of the Atrial Flow Regulator may cause undesired side effects and discomfort.
The rates of previously observed adverse events and complaints with Atrial Flow Regulator and catheter-based implant methods are low.
However, problems may occur, which the doctor will discuss and assess with you.
<br w:type="page"/>The following device and procedural risks are listed according to the expected frequency of occurrence based on available data:
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">Symbol</cf>
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">Meaning</cf>
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">< </cf>
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">less than</cf>

<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">less than or equal to</cf>
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">> </cf>
<cf complexscriptsfont="Arial" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">greater than</cf>

<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Frequent (>5% to 10%):</cf>
Excess fluid in the lungs
Infections, including a bacterial infection of the inner layer of the heart or the heart valves
trans-unit.note: Bacterial infection = Bakterielle Infektion Infection = Infektion
Bacterial infection = Bakterielle Infektion Infection = Infektion

trans-unit.source: Irregular heart rhythm
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Occasional (>2% to 5%):</cf>
<cf size="12">Bleeding, hemorrhage, or bruising requiring treatment</cf>
trans-unit.note: Bleeding = Bluten Hemorrhage = Blutung Bruising = Blaue Flecken
Bleeding = Bluten Hemorrhage = Blutung Bruising = Blaue Flecken

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Blood clot that blocks veins or arteries</cf>
<cf size="12">Bruise which happens when blood collects/pools under the skin</cf>
<cf size="12">Chest pain</cf>
<cf size="12">Death</cf>
<cf size="12">Fluid collects in the sac surrounding the heart which puts pressure on the heart and may prevent it from pumping well</cf>
<cf size="12">Injury to the artery, vein or nerves in the groin or neck needing surgical repair</cf>
<cf size="12">Severe drop in oxygen saturation and sudden or gradual onset of the signs and symptoms of heart failure</cf>
trans-unit.note: Oxygen saturation = Sauerstoffsaettigung Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen
Oxygen saturation = Sauerstoffsaettigung Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Severe pain in the chest, often also spreading to the shoulders, arms, and neck, caused by an inadequate blood supply to the heart</cf>
<cf size="12">Shortness of breath</cf>
<cf size="12">Worsening heart failure (right and left), worsening of function of the right ventricle of the heart</cf>
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">Remote (> 0.2% -to 2%):</cf>
<cf size="12">Air around or outside the lung</cf>
A blood clot that moves through the device (i.e., paradoxical embolus or thrombus formation on the device), potentially leading to a stroke
trans-unit.note: Embolus = Embolus Thrombus = Thrombus Stroke = Schlaganfall
Embolus = Embolus Thrombus = Thrombus Stroke = Schlaganfall

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Deficiency of red blood cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, resulting in fatigue</cf>
<cf size="12">Excess fluid in the legs or arms</cf>
<cf size="12">Excess fluid in the space around the heart</cf>
<cf size="12">Fainting</cf>
<cf size="12">Low or high blood pressure</cf>
<cf size="12">Device Embolization (Movement of the device to an unintended location with resulting obstruction of an organ or vessel)</cf>
trans-unit.note: Device embolization = Embolisation bedingt durch Medizinprodukt Obstruction = Obstruktion
Device embolization = Embolisation bedingt durch Medizinprodukt Obstruction = Obstruktion

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Paresthesia (an abnormal sensation, typically tingling or pricking (“pins and needles”), caused chiefly by pressure on or damage to nerves)</cf>
trans-unit.note: Paresthesia = Paraesthesie Tingling = Kribbeln Pins and needles = Nadelstiche
Paresthesia = Paraesthesie Tingling = Kribbeln Pins and needles = Nadelstiche

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Re-intervention or surgical intervention (an invasive technique to treat, take action, or prevent disease or improve health)</cf>
<cf size="12">Sepsis (a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's response to an infection damages its own tissues)</cf>
<cf size="12">Stroke</cf>
<cf size="12">Vomiting</cf>
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on" size="12">Unknown frequency; expected to be rare/highly unlikely:</cf>
<cf size="12">Allergic reactions</cf>
<cf size="12">An abnormal connection between an artery and a vein</cf>
<cf size="12">An injury to the nerves that send signals from the spinal cord to the shoulder, arm, and hand</cf>
<cf size="12">Cardiac / vascular perforation (a small hole in the heart tissue or blood vessels)</cf>
<cf size="12">Deprivation of oxygen</cf>
<cf size="12">Headache, including migraine, neck or head pain</cf>
trans-unit.note: Headache = Kopfschmerzen Migraine = Migraene Head pain = Kopfschmerz Pain = Schmerz
Headache = Kopfschmerzen Migraine = Migraene Head pain = Kopfschmerz Pain = Schmerz

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Heart attack</cf>
<cf size="12">Injury to blood vessel wall and the leaking blood collects in the surrounding tissue</cf>
<cf size="12">Injury of the esophagus (from the use of the TEE probe) or heart</cf>
<cf size="12">Leakage of air into the veins, or heart</cf>
<cf size="12">Pacemaker insertion secondary to device placement</cf>
<cf size="12">Pacing device malfunction, valve dysfunction or difficulty to exchange pacing lead associated with pacing lead or pacemaker entrapment</cf>
trans-unit.note: Device malfunction = Funktionsstoerung eines Medizinprodukts Lead = Blei
Device malfunction = Funktionsstoerung eines Medizinprodukts Lead = Blei

trans-unit.source: Pulmonary hypertension, which occurs when the pressure in blood vessels leading from the heart to the lungs is too high
trans-unit.note: Pulmonary hypertension = Pulmonale Hypertonie Hypertension = Hypertonie
Pulmonary hypertension = Pulmonale Hypertonie Hypertension = Hypertonie

trans-unit.source: <cf size="12">Seizure</cf>
<cf size="12">Swelling/irritation of the thin saclike membrane surrounding the heart</cf>
<cf size="12">Temporary cessation of breathing</cf>
<cf size="12" complexscriptssize="12">There are also risks associated with the use of anesthesia.

</cf><cf complexscriptsbold="on" size="12" complexscriptssize="12">Common side effects of general anesthesia include nausea and vomiting, dry mouth, sore throat or hoarseness, chills, confusion, dizziness, muscle aches, itching and difficulty urinating.
trans-unit.note: General anesthesia = Allgemeine Anaesthesie Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Nausea = Uebelkeit Vomiting = Erbrechen Dry mouth = Mundtrockenheit Sore throat = Rauer Hals Hoarseness = Heiserkeit Chills = Schuettelfrost Confusion = Verwirrtheit Dizziness = Schwindelgefuehl Itching = Jucken

General anesthesia = Allgemeine Anaesthesie Anesthesia = Ausgeschaltetes Schmerzempfinden Nausea = Uebelkeit Vomiting = Erbrechen Dry mouth = Mundtrockenheit Sore throat = Rauer Hals Hoarseness = Heiserkeit Chills = Schuettelfrost Confusion = Verwirrtheit Dizziness = Schwindelgefuehl Itching = Jucken

trans-unit.source: Serious, life threatening side effects such as heart rhythm disturbances, strokes or accidents causing brain damage can occur.</cf>
Tissue or device erosion (wearing down)
<cf size="12">Trans Ischemic Attack (TIA) (a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke)</cf>
<br w:type="page"/><cf size="12">Valvular regurgitation (heart valve does not close properly)</cf>
<cf size="12">Worsening or new formation of excess fluid in the heart or lungs mostly 1 to 6 weeks after cardiac surgery</cf>
Because the Atrial Flow Regulator device is new there may be other risks that are not known at this time.
Clopidogrel and aspirin are drugs that thin your blood and may prevent clots from forming on your device.

Reported risks associated with medicine (aspirin and clopidogrel) used after implantation of the Atrial Flow Regulator to thin the blood include, but are not limited to, increased bleeding time, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, drowsiness, dizziness, headache, nausea and vomiting, rash, and bruising.
trans-unit.note: Bleeding = Bluten Bleeding time = Blutungszeit Drowsiness = Benommenheit Dizziness = Schwindelgefuehl Headache = Kopfschmerzen Nausea = Uebelkeit Vomiting = Erbrechen Rash = Ausschlag Bruising = Blaue Flecken

Bleeding = Bluten Bleeding time = Blutungszeit Drowsiness = Benommenheit Dizziness = Schwindelgefuehl Headache = Kopfschmerzen Nausea = Uebelkeit Vomiting = Erbrechen Rash = Ausschlag Bruising = Blaue Flecken

trans-unit.source: There may be other risks related to these medicines used to thin the blood that are unknown at this time.
There may be risks associated with trying to remove the AFR device.
Once the device is implanted, an already implanted Atrial Flow Regulator can only be removed for clear medical reasons.
Cardiac surgery following device placement may be more difficult.
If you are in the sham procedure group, there may be risks of delaying treatment including worsening heart failure.

In addition to the known risks above, because this treatment or procedure has not been studied in pregnant women, there may be additional risks to you (or to your embryo or fetus, if you are or may become pregnant, or are nursing an infant) which are unknown at this time.
<bookmarkStart number="7" w:name="_Hlk112413568"/>If you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant during the study, you will not be able to participate.<bookmarkEnd number="7"/>
Notify your doctor immediately if you become pregnant while taking part in this study.
EXPECTED IMPACT AND BENEFITS
Having the Atrial Flow Regulator implanted may relieve some of your heart failure symptoms without open-heart surgery and you may be able to stop some medications.
trans-unit.note: Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Surgery = Operativer Eingriff
Heart failure = Kardiales Versagen Surgery = Operativer Eingriff

trans-unit.source: Usually, the pain after the implant procedure is much less than open- heart surgery and your stay in the hospital is usually much shorter.
The recovery time can be faster and there is little scarring.
There is no guarantee that you will personally benefit from participation in this study.
However, it is possible that the experience gained from the study can help future patients.
ALTERNATIVE TREATMENT
If you choose not to participate in this study at this time, your doctor will discuss alternative treatments with you.
Treatment options may include additional medication, implantation of FDA approved devices, the use of drugs to prevent the occurrence of symptoms, or not having any treatment at all.
Your doctor will explain the benefits and risks associated with the implantation of the Atrial Flow Regulator and the sham procedure, as well as the alternative treatments to you.
Please ask your doctor if you have any questions.
If you do not wish to take part in the study, you will receive the established treatment/ one of the alternative treatments mentioned above.
No disadvantage of any kind shall arise for you.
COSTS AND REIMBURESMENT OF EXPENSES

You will not be billed for the study device<bookmarkStart number="9" w:name="_Hlk112413606"/> or implantation of the study device<bookmarkEnd number="9"/>; however, your insurance will be billed for any routine care (standard of care) that is given to you.
You may be required to pay deductibles or any co-payments that are associated with your insurance.
Some of the tests that are done as part of this study may not be covered by your insurance.
You should check with your insurance company to determine what is and what is not covered before participating in this study.

<bookmarkStart number="10" w:name="_Hlk112413672"/>The sponsor will cover the cost of assessments and procedures required only for this study<cf font="Calibri" asiantextfont="Calibri" complexscriptsfont="Calibri" size="11" complexscriptssize="11">.</cf>
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">PAYMENTS</cf>
After each office visit completed, you will receive a $75 stipend.
If the total payment you receive from Northwell Health, during this year, is equal to $600 or more, the payment is required to be reported to the IRS.
While this study may not pay $600, if you participate in other Northwell Health studies, it is possible your payment could end up totaling $600.
If this occurs, the payment you receive will be reported to the IRS.
In this case, you will be issued a 1099 form and be required to provide your social security at that time for reporting purposes.
You will also be responsible for reporting this income while filing your tax return.
<cf bold="on" complexscriptsbold="on">INJURY</cf>
If you have an injury from the study device, the reasonable medical expenses required to treat such injury or illness may be reimbursed by the study sponsor.

The coverage for such injury or illness is only available if the principal investigator and study sponsor have decided that the injury/illness is directly related to the study device, or properly performed procedures that you would not have undergone but for your participation in this study and is not the result of a pre-existing condition or underlying illness, whether or not previously diagnosed, or the normal progression of your disease, or the improper actions of the study doctor or institution.
If you are injured by the study, contact the study doctor immediately.
The study doctor will treat you or refer you for treatment.
<bookmarkStart number="11" w:name="_Hlk112413834"/>No other compensation will be offered by the sponsor or Northwell, including for things such as lost wages or discomfort.
You are not waiving any legal right to seek additional compensation through the courts by signing this form.
VOLUNTARY PARTICIPATION IN STUDY
Your participation in the clinical study is entirely voluntary.
It is your choice whether to participate or not.
If you decide not to take part or if you want to stop your participation at any time your standard treatment will be continued.
There will be no penalty or loss of benefits to which you are otherwise entitled and there will be no effect on your access to medical care.
If you do choose to participate, you will be asked to sign an informed consent form.
Even after you have signed the informed consent you may stop participating without a reason at any time you choose.
In case you decide to stop participating in the study it is necessary to inform the study doctor right away.
Once the investigator has received this information, they will probably ask you for a final examination visit.
Thereafter, no further data will be collected.
The data recorded up to this point will be evaluated for purposes of this study.
Upon discontinuation of the study, please discuss your future medical treatment with your doctor.

If new information during the clinical study is obtained that may affect your decision to further participate, you will be told about this new information and given the chance to change your mind at any time.
The study doctor may also end your participation at any time if the doctor thinks it’s in your best interest.
The sponsor and authorities responsible for medical devices also have the right to terminate your participation.
During implantation it may become apparent that the Atrial Flow Regulator is not suitable for you and therefore you will not be included in this study and your participation will end.
COLLECTION, PROCESSING AND PRIVATE POLICY OF STUDY DATA
If you decide to participate in this study, your personal data and medical records will be collected and saved for study purposes by the investigating doctor and medical staff.
Your data will be treated confidentially.

The sponsor will make every effort to protect the confidentiality of your data to the extent permitted by law, however complete privacy and confidentiality cannot be guaranteed as there may be conditions where records could be released.
Your data will be deidentified, which means that all information about you will be deleted and replaced by codes before it is entered into a computer database.
To ensure that the study is carried out properly, it may be necessary that representatives from the FDA or other agencies that monitor medical devices may view your data and original medical records.

With your consent to participate in the study you agree that representatives of both the sponsor and FDA or other regulatory agencies including Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) or Ethic Committees (EC), who monitor medical product safety may see your medical records to ensure the proper conduct of the study.
Core labs and contract research organizations assisting with the study may also have access to your data.
A description of this clinical trial will be available on <hyperlink Id="1" tkn="17362">http://www.ClinicalTrials.gov</hyperlink>, as required by U.S. Law.
This Web site will not include information that can identify you.
At most, the Web site will include a summary of the results.
You can search this Web site at any time.
http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/
The results from this study may be published in scientific journals or forwarded to authorities for medical surveillance worldwide.
In these cases, your data is marked with a patient code number.

Only the above-mentioned persons (national or international regulatory authorities, representatives of the sponsor), you, your study doctor and their medical staff can match your identity information to the recorded data.
The sponsor may use the data collected in this study for future unspecified medical research purposes.
Whom to Contact

During this clinical trial, if you have any further questions, concerns, complaints, or research- related injuries connected to your participation, please contact the Investigator (Study Doctor) below.
If you have questions concerns, complaints or for information concerning the rights of research subjects, please contact:
You will be informed in a timely manner of any relevant information pertaining to this clinical study.
Your participation in this clinical investigation is voluntary.
Your decision whether to participate will not prejudice your future care with this institution.
If you decide to participate, you are free to stop participation at any time without any consequences.
You will be given a copy of this signed form to keep.
I have read and understand the above statements and voluntarily consent to participate in this study.

A witness can be a member of the research team, but cannot be the same person signing consent as the investigator)</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14" underlinestyle="single">AUTHORIZATION TO USE AND DISCLOSE PROTECTED HEALTH INFORMATION</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">I also agree to permit Northwell Health Human Research Protection Program, my doctors, and my other health care providers to disclose health information in my medical records to the Researchers, Occlutech, and the FDA or other regulatory authorities for the purposes described below.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The health information that may be used and disclosed includes:</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">All information collected during the research as described in the Informed Consent Form; and</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Health information in my medical records that is relevant to the research described in the Informed Consent Form.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The Researchers may:</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Use and share my health information to conduct the research;</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information to the sponsor of research, Occlutech and its agents;</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information as required by law;</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information to representatives of government organizations and other persons who are required to watch over the safety and effectiveness of medical products and therapies and the conduct of research; and representatives of Northwell Health’s Human Research Protection Program (the group of people who oversee human subjects research).</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Remove from my health information, my name and other information that could be used to identify me.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">OCCLUTECH may:</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Use and share my health information to conduct the research;</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information as described in the Informed Consent;</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information as required by law;</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Disclose my health information to representatives of government organizations and other persons who are required to watch over the safety and effectiveness of medical products and therapies and the conduct of research; and</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Remove from my health information my name and other information that could be used to identify me.</cf>

<cf bold="on" size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Once information that could be used to identify me has been removed, </cf><cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">the information that remains is no longer subject to this Authorization and may be used and disclosed by the Researchers and Occlutech as permitted by law.</cf>

<cf bold="on" size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Once my health information has been disclosed to a third party, </cf><cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">federal privacy laws may no longer protect it from further disclosure.
However, the Researchers and Occlutech agree to protect my health information by using and disclosing it only as permitted by me in this Authorization and the Informed Consent.
Also, no publication about the research will reveal my identity without my specific written permission.
These limitations continue even if I revoke (take back) this Authorization.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Please note that:</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">You do not have to sign this Authorization, but if you do not, you will not be allowed to participate in the research.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">However, if you revoke this Authorization, you will no longer be allowed to participate in the research.

Also, even if you revoke this Authorization, the information already obtained by the Researchers and Occlutech may be used and disclosed as permitted by the Authorization and the Informed Consent.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">While the research is in progress, you will not be allowed to see your health information that is created or collected in the course of the research.
After the research is finished, however, you may see this information as described in the (hospital/clinical trial site}’s Notice of Information practices.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">This Authorization will be good until December 31, 2070.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">You will be given a copy of this Authorization after you have signed it.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Print Name of Subject</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Signature of Subject</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Date</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Date</cf>
<br w:type="page"/><cf bold="on" size="14" complexscriptssize="14">AUTHORIZATION TO USE AND DISCLOSE PROTECTED HEALTH INFORMATION</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The following sections provide a specific description of how your information will be used and disclosed if you participate in this research study.
By signing and dating this form, you are authorizing such access.
If you do not sign and date this form to authorize access, you will not be able to participate in this research study.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">This research study may be performed only by collecting and using your medical information.
Your study records will be kept as confidential as possible.
Only a number and your initials will be used to identify you.
You will not be personally identified in any reports or publications that may result from this research study.
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Because of the research goals of this study, however, your study records cannot be kept completely confidential.
The Sponsor of this study is Occlutech, Inc. </cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The study personnel, the Sponsor, Representatives from Northwell Health’s Human Research Protection Program (the group of people that oversee research at this institution), its agents, and Cardiovascular Research Foundation (CRF) will need to review the medical information collected from you for use in this study to accurately record information for this study.
In addition, to review the study findings, the U.S. FDA, the IRB, and other regulatory agencies may review your medical records.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The medical information that will be collected from you if you participate in the study includes the following:</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Information obtained from procedures to determine your eligibility to participate in the study, including a routine medical history, physical examination, and blood and urine tests.</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Information that is created or collected from you during your participation in the study, including the results of the blood and urine tests and any other procedures performed during the study.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Information contained in your underlying medical records related to your medical history and treatment.</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The above information may identify you by name, address, telephone number, social security number, health plan number, study number, date of birth, dates relating to various medical procedures, and/or other identifying information.</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">If you sign and date this form and you participate in the study, the study personnel will be authorized to use the information described above to carry out the purposes of the research study.
The study personnel will also be authorized to disclose the relevant information described above to the following parties involved in the research study:</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Occlutech, CRF, or other agents designated by Occlutech to collect or review study data for verification of study procedures and/or adverse event (bad side effect) reporting.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The IRB or that oversees the research study at your site.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Government regulatory agencies including the FDA.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Clinical study recruitment company, if you were referred to the study by such a company, for analytical purposes and so they may be compensated.
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Representatives from Northwell Health’s Human Research Protection Program (the group of people that oversee research at this institution)</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Once your information is disclosed to the study sponsors, its agents, the IRB/IEC, or government agencies as described above, there is a potential that your medical information will be re-disclosed and will no longer be protected by U.S. federal privacy regulations.

In addition to disclosures to the entities identified above, CRF may further electronically disclose your coded health information to others involved in the research study, such as the following:</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Laboratories or offsite testing facilities for clinical tests for safety and immune responses as required by study protocols.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Approved offsite storage facilities or cloud service providers to meet study record retention and storage requirements.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The study Sponsor Occlutech, who directs the medical research studies.</cf>

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Other third parties contracted by CRF and/or Occlutech to provide services related to studies and reporting of confirmed COVID-19 infections or test results to public health authorities.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">The study data may be transferred to other countries for processing, including countries not covered by data protection legislation.
The laws of state where you live may provide further protection.
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">While the study is in progress, your access to your study records will be temporarily suspended.
You will be able to access your information when the research study is completed.

You have the right to see and copy the medical information collected from you in the course of the study for as long as that information is maintained by the study personnel and other entities participant to federal privacy regulation.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Study data, including your coded medical information, may be used and shared by the Sponsor.
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">You may withdraw your authorization at any time by sending a written request to the study doctor listed on page one of this informed consent.
You have the right to require that any previously retained samples are destroyed.
If you withdraw your authorization, data collected prior to your withdrawal may still be processed along with other data collected as part of the study.
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Normally no new information will be collected for the study database unless you specifically authorize that.
However, the law does require that any side affects you may suffer are documented and reported.
To complete the study findings, your long-term health status may also be obtained from public sources.
In California and any other state that requires an expiration date, the Authorization will expire 50 years after you sign and date this authorization document.</cf>
<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">I understand that I have the right to refuse to sign and date this authorization, which will result in my inability to participate in the study.
You will receive a copy of this authorization after you have signed and dated it.

<cf size="14" complexscriptssize="14">Signature of Participant
Date</cf>
